item.title: Why MySQL timestamp is 24 seconds different from PHP
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: You may find that timestamp value returned by MySQL UNIX_TIMESTAMP() function is 24 seconds grater than those returned by PHP functions and classes like strtotime(), mktime(), DateTime::getTimestamp(), Zend_Date::getTimestamp(). via Why MySQL timestamp is 24 seconds different from PHP | Pumka.net Blog. Turns out MySQL applies leap seconds, but PHP doesn’t.
item.content:encoded:
You may find that timestamp value returned by MySQL UNIX_TIMESTAMP() function is 24 seconds grater than those returned by PHP functions and classes like strtotime(), mktime(), DateTime::getTimestamp(), Zend_Date::getTimestamp().

via Why MySQL timestamp is 24 seconds different from PHP | Pumka.net Blog.

Turns out MySQL applies leap seconds, but PHP doesn’t.
